comment.author: 110063046@N07
comment._content:
He's not on the Post Office appointment books (available through the BPMA/Ancestry) so most likely an employee of another Civil Service department. POR officers weren't necessarily Post Office employees. I'll try and find some more information (Post Office employees and their backgrounds is my PhD thesis area).

The information available on Ancestry details the following:

He appears on the list of 'British Officer Prisoners of War' as a Second Lieutenant with the date missing as May 1916. It reads on that he was repatriated on the 13 December 1918 and the section was 'Western Theatre of Operations'. 

His medal card reads 'exonerated officers List A' as a Lieutenant, no date given though.

There is only one Neville Ames on the 1911 census. It reads that he was born in 1892 in London and was working as an Insurance Office Clerk, whilst living in Fulham with his mother and two servants.

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: Neville Lawrenson Ames birth recorded 3rd qr 1891 in Fulham Neville L Ames marriage recorded to Mary A Holden-White 4th qr 1924 in Hampstead Neville L Ames marriage recorded to Honor R M Maule 1st qr 1955 in Kensington Neville L Ames death recorded age 64 1st qr 1956 in Marylebone www.freebmd.org.uk

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: Source: The Cricketer Neville Ames Full name:Neville Lawrenson Ames Born:31st July 1891, Fulham, London, England Died:21st March 1956, Marylebone, London, England Batting:Right-hand batsman Bowling:Right-arm fast-medium Education:Radley College Teams:HDG Leveson-Gower's XI (Other FC: 1912); Radley College (Miscellaneous: 1908-1910) This is followed by lists of matches and more detailed statistics stats.thecricketer.com/Players/27/27471/27471.html Radley College is a boys' independent boarding school near Radley, Abingdon, Oxfordshire.
